Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Approach to Study Nonlinearity and Interaction in Regression
Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing access to large databases across many global economic sectors, as well as various scientific disciplines, poses significant challenges that demand novel statistical methodologies for conducting data analytics. A common feature of these databases is the large number of subjects under study, and the large number of variables describing a wide variety of attributes attached to each subject. Guided by the dual principles of parsimony and accuracy, statistical models can be developed to serve as informative approximations to the unknown physical reality underlying the intricate mechanism of the data generation process. However, a lack of understanding of the nature and the pattern of complex nonlinear interactions between variables involved in the system has largely hindered the progress in the field of high-dimensional data analysis. In this project, novel statistical theory, methods, and software will be developed. These results will address key foundational issues and open up new avenues for research.

Regression is one of the most fundamental concepts in statistics, with applications in almost all disciplines. The growing interest in high-dimensional regression either from the forward or from the inverse perspective has brought out many facets that increase its flexibility in modeling complex data with proven statistical efficiency. Working in the data-intensive area of genomics, a novel statistical notion, liquid association (LA), has been developed that allows researchers to study dynamic patterns of co-regulation between genes. This project will investigate methods of employing LA for variable selection in high-dimensional regression. In combination with inverse modeling techniques including sliced inverse regression (SIR), hidden patterns of interaction between clusters of nonlinearly-correlated variables can be revealed. In many applications, it is often necessary to incorporate a certain set of background variables that are known to be important in the model. This adds another layer of complexity in revealing patterns in the interlocked variable-to-variable interactions. Methods of marginalizing the interference caused by background variables will also be developed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As data science has become a household name,  more and more new challenges in analyzing large volume of data with great complexity are encountered. In life science, many bioinformatic tools have been developed to investigate high throughput assays such as  the expression of tens of thousands of human genes, DNA  mutation, copy number variation and  methylation profiles. Motivated by the  application in genomics, liquid association (LA) is a statistics notion that depicts the change in the covariation of the expression of two genes as some (but unknown to biologists ) cellular conditions vary. 

The lack of the understanding about the nature and the pattern of complex nonlinear interaction between variables ( such as expression of different genes) is a bottleneck in advancing the field of high dimensional data analysis. The theory, method and software are developed in this project  to leverage the notion of LA  and open up the opportunities of more systematic studies on this important topic.  Intriguing issues  concerning the nonlinear confounding between the regressor nonlinearity and the response nonlinearity as well as hidden patterns of interaction between clusters of nonlinearly-correlated variables can be addressed by the new LA methodology.

The speed of computation is a main issue in applying LA to large datasets. We showed how to take advantage of Graphic Processing Units (GPUs) for speeding up the LA computing. A GPU version of LA has been programmed.  The improvement of GALA over the traditional CPU-alone version of LA  on seven public available gene expression datasets have been demonstrated, achieving nearly 200-fold  acceleration.  A companion package in R was developed for facilitating follow-up analysis and improving user experience.  See the publication ?GPU Accelerated Liquid Association GALA ? (Statistics and Its Interface Volume 13 (2020) 119?125 ). 

Regarding broader impacts, this work benefits the researchers of various discipline including bioinformatics, socioeconomics, and machine learning applications such as natural language processing. As a showcase example in the GALA paper,  LA methodology is applied to aid cost/efficiency evaluation between different health care systems in different nations, using Global Health Observatory(GHO) data.The GHO data website is WHO?s gateway to health-related statistics in its 194 Member States. A key finding is the association between FD75  (Number of females dying between age 75 and age 79) and FMR (female age-standardized mortality rate by all causes ) are dynamically influenced by GGE (General government expenditure on health as a percentage of total government expenditure). For low GGE countries, FD75 and FMR are negatively correlated. In contrast, for high GGE countries,  FD75 and FMR are positively correlated. 

Two Ph D students participating in this work have graduated.  GALA and  two other papers ( ?A folksonomy-based approach for profiling human perception on word similarity?, ICNLSP 2019, URL: https://www.aclweb.org/anthology/W19-7413;"A weight-relaxed model averaging approach for high dimensional generalized linear models"  Annals of Statistics. Volume 45, Number 6 (2017), 2654-2679 ) have been published along with software packages,  which can be downloaded for free usage in  the data-science education and free dissemination to promote equity, diversity and inclusion.  Various self-training opportunities are opened up to the broader society of various under-represented groups. Their quantitative reasoning ability to exploit world-wide database accessible through internet, including government and industry, medicine and public health, will be enhanced. This helps the development of the data-intensive workforce and increases the economic competitiveness of our nation.
